summary.long: 2 Chronicles is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: As David’s son Solomon consolidated his administration, the Lord his God was with him to make him very successful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon addressed the entire nation of Israel, including the commanders of thousands and hundreds, the judges, all the other leaders of Israel, and all of the heads of the ancestral houses of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon, along with the whole assembly with him, met at the high place in Gibeon because that’s where God’s Tent of Meeting that the Lord’s servant Moses had constructed in the wilderness was located.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, David had brought the Ark of God from Kiriath-jearim to the place that David had prepared for it, after having erected a tent for it in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, the bronze altar that Uri’s son Bezalel, Hur’s grandson, had erected, was in place in front of the Lord’s tent. Solomon and the assembly sought the Lord there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon approached the presence of the Lord at the bronze altar that had been placed at the Tent of Meeting and offered 1,000 burnt offerings on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That very night God appeared to Solomon and told him, “Ask what I am to give you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon replied to God, “You showed great gracious love to my father David, and have established me as king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, Lord God, your promise to my father David is fulfilled, because you have made me king over a people as numerous as the dust of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give me wisdom now, so I may go in and out among this people, because who can rule this great people that belongs to you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God told Solomon, “Since you had this in mind, to ask neither to focus on riches, wealth, honor, or the lives of those who hate you, nor have you requested a long life, but instead you have asked for wisdom and knowledge for yourself, so that you may rule my people over whom I have established you as king,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: wisdom and knowledge have been granted to you. Furthermore, I will give you riches, wealth, and honor—such as none of the kings owned who lived before you and none after you are to ever attain their equal.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon returned from the Tent of Meeting at the high place in Gibeon to Jerusalem, where he reigned over Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon amassed both chariots and horsemen: he owned 1,400 chariots and 12,000 horsemen, stationing them in armories and with the king in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king made silver and gold as common in Jerusalem as stones, and made cedar trees as plentiful as sycamore trees that grow in the Shephelah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon’s horses were imported from Egypt and from Kue; the king’s procurement officials obtained them from Kue at great price.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Chariots were imported from Egypt for 600 shekels each, and horses cost 150 shekels each, and then they exported them to all of the kings of the Hittites and to the kings of Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Solomon was determined to build a temple dedicated to the Name of the Lord as well as his own royal palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon conscripted 70,000 men to do heavy work, 80,000 men to quarry in the hill country, and 3,600 to supervise them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Solomon also sent this message to King Hiram of Tyre:
“Just as you did with my father David, sending him cedars to build him a palace to live in, do the same for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, I’m building a temple dedicated to the name of the Lord my God, to his glory, so we can burn fragrant incense in his presence, display rows of the bread of his presence continuously, and make burnt offerings in the morning, evening, on Sabbath days, during New Moon festivals, and during appointed festivals scheduled by the Lord our God. This is mandated forever in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Temple that I’m building will be great, because the greatness of our God surpasses that of all gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But who can build a temple for him, since neither heaven nor the highest of the heavens can contain him? So who am I, that I should build a temple to him, except to burn incense in his presence?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “At any rate, send me an individual who is a skilled craftsman in gold, silver, bronze, and iron, as well as in purple, crimson, and blue materials, who knows how to craft engravings, so he may work with the craftsmen whom I have assembled in Judah and Jerusalem, as provided for by my father David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also send me cedar, cypress, and algum timber from Lebanon, since I’m aware that your servants know how to cut down timber from Lebanon. My servants will accompany your servants
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to prepare an abundant amount of timber for me, because the Temple that I’m building is to be great and awesome.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now look! I will pay your servants, the lumberjacks who prepare the timber, 20,000 measures of barley, 20,000 baths of wine, and 20,000 baths of oil.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In a letter that he sent to Solomon, King Hiram of Tyre wrote, “Because he loves his people, the Lord has placed you as king over them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hiram also wrote:
“Blessed be the Lord God of Israel, who made the heavens and the earth. He gave King David a wise son, who is acquainted with discretion and understanding, and who is building a temple to the Lord, as well as a royal palace for himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I’m sending along Hiram-abi, a skilled craftsman, who is very creative.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He is the son of a mother from the tribe of Dan, and his father is from Tyre. He’s skilled in working with gold, silver, bronze, iron, stone, and timber, as well as in purple, blue, linen, and crimson materials. He is skilled in engravings, and can craft any design to which he may be assigned. He will work with your skilled artisans and with all of your craftsmen who have been assigned by my lord David, your father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So then, may my lord send to his servants the wheat, barley, oil, and wine about which he has spoken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We’ll cut down the timber you need from Lebanon and transport it to you on rafts by sea to Joppa, so you can move it to Jerusalem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon took a census of all the non-Israeli men who lived in the land of Israel, after the census that his father David had taken, and 153,600 were counted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He conscripted 70,000 of them to do heavy work, 80,000 to quarry in the hill country, and 3,600 men to supervise the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon began construction of the Lord’s Temple in Jerusalem on Mount Moriah where the Lord had appeared to his father David, that is, where David had prepared Ornan the Jebusite’s threshing floor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He began construction on the second day of the second month of the fourth year of his reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the foundations that Solomon set in place for God’s Temple. The length in terms of the former standard measurements: 60 cubits; its width: 20 cubits.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A portico extended in front of the Temple for its entire width of 20 cubits, and was 120 cubits high. Inside he had it overlaid with pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The main room of the Temple was trimmed with a wainscoting composed of cypress wood, overlaid with fine gold ornamented with palm trees and chains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Temple was adorned with precious stones, including gold from the Orient.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Temple was overlaid with gold, including the beams, thresholds, walls, and doors. Cherubim were engraved on the walls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With respect to the Most Holy Place in the Temple, its length across the width of the Temple was 20 cubits, and its width extended 20 cubits.
Solomon overlaid it with 600 talents of pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The gold nails weighed 50 shekels. He also overlaid the upper rooms with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He crafted two cherubim from wood, overlaid them with gold, and placed them in the Most Holy Place in the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wingspan of the cherubim was 20 cubits; the wing of one, five cubits long, touched the wall of the Temple, and its other wing, five cubits long, touched the wing of the other cherub.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wing of the other cherub, five cubits long, touched the opposite wall of the Temple and its other wing, five cubits long, touched the wing of the first cherub.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wings of these cherubim extended for 20 cubits as they stood on their feet and faced the front of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He constructed the veil from blue, purple, crimson, and fine linen, embroidering cherubim on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made two pillars 35 cubits high for the front of the Temple, topped by a capital that was five cubits high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He crafted chains for the inner sanctuary and placed them on top of the pillars, attaching 100 pomegranates to each of the chains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He set up the pillars at the front of the Temple, one on the south side of the entrance and the other on the north side of the entrance. He named the south pillar Jachin and the north pillar Boaz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon also constructed a bronze altar 20 cubits long, 20 cubits wide, and ten cubits high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He crafted a circular sea of cast metal 10 cubits from rim to rim and five cubits tall. A line 30 cubits long surrounded it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Underneath, figurines resembling oxen encircled the circular sea beneath it, ten oxen every cubit, and encircling the sea completely. The oxen were in two rows, cast all at the same time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sea stood on top of twelve oxen, three of which faced to the north, three of which faced to the west, three of which faced to the south, and three of which faced toward the east. The sea was placed on top of the oxen, with all of their hindquarters turned inwards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was a handbreadth thick, with its brim fashioned like the brim of a cup. Similar in shape to a lily blossom, it could hold 3,000 baths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon also made ten wash basins, placing five on the right side and five on the left. The basins were intended for use to rinse burnt offerings, and the sea was intended for use by the priests to wash in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon made ten gold lamp stands as he had been directed and set them in the Temple, five on the south side and five on the north side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made ten tables and placed them in the Temple, five on the right side and five on the left side. He also constructed 100 gold basins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made the court of the priests, the great court, and doors for the court, overlaying their doors with bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He set the sea at the southeast corner of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram-abi crafted the pots, shovels, and basins, thus completing the work that he did for King Solomon on the Temple of God;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that is, the two pillars, the bowls, the two capitals on top of the pillars, the two lattice works that covered the two bowls for the capitals that were on top of the pillars;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the 400 pomegranate-shaped ornaments for the latticework of the two pillars (each latticework having two rows of ornaments at the bowl-shaped top of each pillar);
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the ten stands with their ten basins;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the large bronze basin called the Sea with the twelve oxen underneath,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: along with its pots, shovels, forks, and all of its other implements that Hiram-abi made from polished bronze for King Solomon and the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king had them forged in the clay ground between Succoth and Zeredah in the Jordan plain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon made so many utensils in such great quantities that the weight of the bronze was never fully recorded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon also made these items for God’s Temple: the golden altar, the tables for the Bread of the Presence,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the lamp stands and their lamps made of pure gold to burn in front of the inner sanctuary, as required,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the pure gold ornaments in the shape of flowers, the lamps, and the tongs (all made of the purest gold),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the gold trimming instruments, basins, pans, censers, and the gold door sockets for the inner sanctuary (that is, the Most Holy Place), and for the doors to the main hall of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as Solomon had completed the Lord’s Temple, he installed the holy items that had belonged to his father David, including the silver, gold, and all the other items in the treasure rooms of God’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon called Israel’s elders together, including all the leaders of the tribes and families of Israel. They met in Jerusalem to transfer the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord from Zion, the City of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the men of Israel assembled in front of the king during the Festival of Tents that takes place in the seventh month of the year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as all of Israel’s elders had arrived, the descendants of Levi lifted the ark
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and carried it, the tent where God met with his people, and all of the sacred implements that belonged in the tent. The Levitical priests carried these up to the City of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon and all the Israelis who had assembled together proceeded ahead of the ark and sacrificed more sheep and oxen than could be counted or recorded due to the number of sacrifices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests transported the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord to the place created for it within the inner sanctuary of the Temple, into the Most Holy Place under the wings of the cherubim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wings of the cherubim extended over where the ark and its carrying poles had been placed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but the poles were long enough for their ends to extend to the front of the inner sanctuary, even though they could not be seen from outside. They remain there to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was nothing in the ark except for the two tablets that Moses had placed there while Israel was encamped at Horeb, where the Lord made a covenant with the Israelis after he had brought them out of the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, the priests vacated the Holy Place. (Meanwhile, all the priests who were participating consecrated themselves, irrespective of their Levitical divisions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the musicians who were descendants of Levi, including Asaph, Heman, Jeduthun, and their sons and relatives wore linen and played cymbals and stringed instruments as they stood east of the altar. Accompanied by 120 priests who played trumpets,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the trumpeters and musicians played in union, praising and giving thanks to the Lord. They praised the Lord loudly and sang, “He is good, and his gracious love is eternal,” accompanied by the trumpets, cymbals, and other musical instruments.) As they did this, a cloud filled the Temple, that is, the Lord’s Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the priests were unable to complete their duties because of the cloud, since the glory of the Lord had filled God’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon said, “The Lord has said that he lives shrouded in darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I have constructed a magnificent temple dedicated to you that will serve as a place for you to inhabit forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king turned to face the entire congregation of Israel while the congregation of Israel remained standing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Solomon prayed:
“Blessed is the Lord God of Israel, who made a commitment to my father David and then personally fulfilled what he had promised when he said:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘From the day I brought out my people from the land of Egypt I never chose a city from all the tribes of Israel to build a temple where my name might reside. And I never chose any man to become Commander-in-Chief over my people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I have chosen Jerusalem, where my name will reside. And I have chosen David to be over my people Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “My father David wanted to build a temple for the name of the Lord God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord told my father David:
‘Therefore, since you determined to build a temple for my name, you acted well, because it was your choice to do so.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, you are not to build the Temple, but your son who will be born to you is to build a temple for my name.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Lord has brought to fulfillment what he promised, and now here I stand, having succeeded my father David to sit on the throne of Israel, as the Lord promised. I have built the Temple for the name of the Lord God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have placed in it the ark in which the covenant that the Lord made with the Israelis is stored.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon took his place in front of the Lord’s altar in the presence of the entire congregation of Israel and spread out his hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had a bronze platform constructed five cubits square and three cubits high. He had it erected in the middle of the courtyard, and stood on it. Then he knelt down on his knees in front of the entire congregation of Israel, spread out his hands toward heaven,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and said:
“Lord God of Israel, there is no one like you, God of heaven and earth, who watches over his covenant, showing gracious love to your servants who live their lives in your presence with all their hearts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is you, Lord God, who has kept your promise to my father, your servant David, that you made to him. Indeed, you made a commitment to my father David and then personally fulfilled what you had promised today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now therefore, Lord God of Israel, keep your promise that you made to my father, your servant David, when you said, ‘You are to not lack a man to sit on the throne of Israel, if only your descendants will watch their lives, to live according to my Law, just as you have lived in my presence.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now therefore, Lord God of Israel, may your promise that you made to your servant David be fulfilled…
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and yet, will God truly reside on earth with human beings? Look! Neither the sky nor the highest heaven can contain you! How much less this Temple that I have built!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pay attention to the prayer of your servant and to his request, Lord my God, and listen to the cry and prayer that your servant is praying in your presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let your eyes always look toward this Temple day and night, toward the location where you have said you would place your name. Listen to the prayer that your servant prays in this direction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Listen to the requests from your servant and from your people Israel as they pray in this direction, and listen from the place where you reside—from heaven!—then hear and forgive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If a man sins against his neighbor and he is required to take an oath, and he then comes to take an oath in front of your altar in this Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then listen from heaven, act, and judge your servants, recompensing the wicked by bringing back to him the consequences of his choices and by justifying the righteous by recompensing him according to his righteousness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If your people Israel are defeated in a battle with their enemy because they have sinned against you, when they return to you and confess to you, pray, and in this Temple they ask you to show grace to them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear from heaven, forgive the sin of your people Israel, and return them to the soil that you gave to them and to their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When the skies remain closed, and there is no rain because they have sinned against you, and they pray in the direction of this place, confessing your name and turning from their sin when you afflict them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear in heaven and forgive the sin of your servants and of your people Israel. Indeed, teach them the best way to live and send rain on your land that you have given to your people as an inheritance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If a famine comes to the land, or if there comes plant diseases, mildew, locusts, or grasshoppers, or if their enemies attack them in their settlements of the land, no matter what the epidemic or illness is,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: whatever prayer or request is made, no matter whether it’s made by a single man or by all of your people Israel, each praying out of his own illness and anguish and stretching out their hands toward this Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear from heaven, the place where you reside, and forgive, repaying each person according to all of his ways, since you know their hearts—for you alone know the hearts of human beings—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so they will fear you and live life your way as long as they live in the land that you have given to our ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now concerning the foreigner who is not from your people Israel, when he comes from a land far away for the sake of your great name, your mighty acts, and your obvious power, when they come and pray in the direction of this Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear from heaven where you reside, and do whatever the foreigner asks of you, so that all the people of the earth may know your name, fear you as do your people Israel, and so they may know that this Temple that I have built is called by your name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When your people go out to war against their enemies, no matter what way you send them, and they pray to you in the direction of this city that you have chosen and in the direction of the Temple that I have built for your name,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear their prayer and their request from heaven, and fight for their cause.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When they sin against you—because there isn’t a single human being who doesn’t sin—and you become angry with them and deliver them over to their enemy, who takes them away captive to a land that’s near or far away,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: if they turn their hearts back to you in the land where they have been taken captive, repent, and pray to you—even if they do so in the land where they have been taken captive—confessing, ‘We have sinned, we have committed abominations, and practiced wickedness,’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: if they return to you with all of their heart and with all of their soul in the land where they have been taken captive, as they pray in the direction of their land that you have given to their ancestors and to the city that you have chosen, and to the Temple that I have built for your name,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear their prayer and requests from heaven, where you reside, and fight for their cause, forgiving your people who have sinned against you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And now, my God, please let your eyes be open and your ears attentive to the prayers that are uttered in this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And now may the Lord God arise, to your place of rest, you, and the ark of your power! Let your priests, Lord God, be clothed with salvation, and cause your godly ones to find their joy in what is good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Lord God, do not turn your face away from your anointed one. Remember your gracious love to your servant David.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as Solomon finished his prayer, fire descended from heaven and burned up the burnt offerings and sacrifices, and the glory of the Lord filled the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests could not enter into the Temple because the glory of the Lord had filled the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: Then the king and all the people kept on offering sacrifices in the presence of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon offered a sacrifice of 22,000 oxen and 120,000 sheep, which is how the king and all of the people dedicated God’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests stood in waiting at their assigned places, along with the descendants of Levi who carried musical instruments used in service to the Lord that King David had made for giving thanks to the Lord—because his gracious love is eternal—whenever David, accompanied by priests sounding trumpets, offered praises while all of Israel stood in the assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon also dedicated the middle of the court in front of the Lord’s Temple by offering there burnt offerings and fat from peace offerings because the bronze altar that Solomon had made could not contain the burnt offerings, grain offerings, and fat portion offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Solomon also held a week-long festival attended by all of Israel. The assembly was very large, and included people from as far away as Lebo-hamath to the Wadi of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the day after the festival ended, they convened a solemn assembly, because they had been dedicating the altar for seven days and observing the festival for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the twenty-third day of the seventh month, King Solomon sent the people back home, and they returned rejoicing and in good spirits because of the goodness that the Lord had shown to David, to Solomon, and to his people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so Solomon completed the Lord’s Temple, bringing to completion everything that he had planned on doing for the Lord’s Temple and for his own palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Later, the Lord appeared to Solomon during the night and told him:
“I have heard your prayer and have chosen this place for a sacrificial temple to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever I close the skies so there is no rain, or whenever I command locusts to lay waste to the land, or whenever I send epidemics among my people,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when my people humble themselves—the ones who are called by my name—and pray, seek me, and turn away from their evil practices, I myself will listen from heaven, I will pardon their sins, and I will restore their land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now therefore my eyes will remain open and my ears will remain listening to the prayers that are offered in this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, I have chosen and have set apart for myself this Temple, intending my name to reside there forever. My eyes and my heart will reside there every day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now as for you, if you commune with me like your father did, doing everything that I have commanded you, including obeying my statutes and my legal decisions,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then I will make your royal throne secure, just as I agreed to do for your father David when I said, ‘You are to not lack a man to rule over Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But if you turn away and abandon my statutes and my commands that I have given you, and if you walk away to serve other gods and worship them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then I will tear them up by the roots from the ground that I had given them! And as for this Temple that I have set apart for my name, I will throw it out of my sight and make it the butt of jokes and a means of ridicule among people worldwide!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Furthermore, even though this Temple seems so exalted, everyone who passes by it will be so astounded that they will ask, ‘Why did the Lord do this to this land and to this Temple?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will answer, ‘Because they abandoned the Lord God of their ancestors, who brought them from the land of Egypt, adopted other gods, worshipped them, and served them, therefore the Lord has brought all of this disaster on them.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It took Solomon 20 years to build the Lord’s Temple and his own palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During this time, he also rebuilt the towns that Hiram had restored to him, and he settled Israelis in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Solomon traveled to Hamath-zobah and captured it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he rebuilt Tadmor in the desert, along with supply centers that he had built in Hamath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also built upper and lower Beth-horon as fortified cities, installing walls, gates, and bars,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he rebuilt Baalath and its supply centers that belonged to Solomon, along with all the cities that he utilized to garrison his chariots and cavalry forces. Solomon was pleased also to build in Jerusalem, in Lebanon, and in every territory that he controlled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of the survivors who remained living in the land but who were not Israelis (including Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: were descendants of the nations whom the people of Israel had not eliminated. Solomon put them to work as conscripted laborers, which they continue to do to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, Solomon never made conscripted laborers from among the Israelis, but they did serve as his army, as his chief captains, and as commanders in charge of his chariots and cavalry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon appointed 250 chief officers to command his army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, Solomon moved Pharaoh’s daughter from the City of David to the palace that he had constructed to house her, because he reasoned, “My wife isn’t going to live in the palace where King David of Israel lived, because wherever the ark of the Lord entered is holy.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon offered burnt offerings to the Lord on the Lord’s altar that he had built in front of the porch of the Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: acting in compliance with the daily rule by offering them in conformity to commands issued by Moses for the Sabbaths, the New Moons, and the three annual festivals (the Festival of Unleavened Bread, the Festival of Weeks, and the Festival of Tents).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Following proscriptions laid down by his father David, Solomon appointed divisions of priests for their service as well as descendants of Levi for duties of praise and ministry before the priests consistent with the daily rules. Furthermore, because David, the man of God, had commanded it, Solomon also appointed gatekeepers to serve by divisions at every gate of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They scrupulously adhered to the orders issued by the king to the priests and descendants of Levi in everything, including matters pertaining to operation of the treasuries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so Solomon completed all of the work, from the day that the foundation stone of the Lord’s Temple was laid until the Lord’s Temple was completely finished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Solomon visited Ezion-geber and Elath at the seashore in the land of Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram sent Solomon ships and servants who were expert mariners, and they sailed with Solomon’s servants to Ophir, where they brought back 450 talents of gold for Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the queen of Sheba heard about Solomon’s reputation, she traveled to Jerusalem and tested him with difficult questions. She brought along a large retinue, camels laden with spices, and lots of gold and precious stones. Upon her arrival, she spoke with Solomon about everything that was on her mind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon answered all of her questions. Because nothing was hidden from Solomon, he hid nothing from her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the queen of Sheba had seen Solomon’s wisdom for herself, the palace that he had built,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the food set at his table, his servants who waited on him, his ministers in attendance and how they were dressed, his personal staff and how they were dressed, and even his personal stairway by which he went up to the Lord’s Temple, she was breathless!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Everything I heard about your wisdom and what you have to say is true!” she gasped,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “but I didn’t believe it at first! But then I came here and I’ve seen it for myself! It’s amazing! I wasn’t told half of what’s really great about your wisdom. You’re far better in person than what the reports have said about you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How blessed are your staff! And how blessed are your employees, who serve you continually and get to listen to your wisdom!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Blessed be the Lord your God, who is delighted with you! He set you in place on his throne to be king for the Lord your God. He made you king over them so you could carry out justice and implement righteousness, because your God loves Israel and intends to establish them forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she gave the king 120 talents of gold, a vast quantity of spices, and precious stones. There were no spices comparable to those that the queen of Sheba gave to King Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram’s servants and Solomon’s servants, who brought gold from Ophir, also presented algum wood and other precious stones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king used the algum wood to have steps made for the Lord’s Temple and for the royal palace, as well as lyres and harps for the choir, and nothing like that wood had been seen before in the territory of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In return, King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba everything she wanted and requested in addition to what she had brought for the king. Afterward, she returned to her own land, accompanied by her servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon received in any given year about 666 talents of gold,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: not including revenue from traders and merchants. In addition, all the kings of Arabia and the governors of the nation brought gold and silver to Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon made 200 large shields of beaten gold, overlaying each shield with the gold from 600 gold pieces,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and 300 shields from beaten gold, overlaying each shield with the gold from 300 gold pieces. The king put them in his palace in the Lebanon forest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king also made a great ivory throne and overlaid it with pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Six steps led up to the throne. A golden footstool was attached to the throne, which had armrests on each side of the seat and two lions standing on either side of each armrest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Twelve lions were placed on both sides of the six steps leading to the throne, and nothing comparable was made for any other kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of King Solomon’s drinking vessels were made of gold, and all the vessels in his palace in the Lebanon forest were made of pure gold. Silver was never considered to be valuable during the lifetime of Solomon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because the king had ships that sailed to Tarshish accompanied by Hiram’s servants. Once every three years ships from Tarshish returned, bringing gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As a result, King Solomon became greater than all the kings of the earth in regards to wealth and wisdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the kings of the earth continued to seek audiences with Solomon so they could hear the wise things that God had put in his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone kept on bringing gifts on an annual basis, including items made of silver and gold, garments, myrrh, spices, horses, and mules.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had 4,000 stalls for horses and chariots, along with 12,000 cavalry soldiers. He stationed them in various chariot cities and with the king in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon ruled over all the kings from the Euphrates River west to the land of the Philistines and as far south as the boundary with Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king made silver as common as stones in Jerusalem, and made cedar trees as abundant as sycamore trees in the Shephelah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also kept bringing horses to Solomon from Egypt and from all of the surrounding countries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the rest of Solomon’s accomplishments, from first to last, are written in the records of Nathan the prophet, in the prophecy of Ahijah the Shilonite, and in the visions of Iddo the seer pertaining to Nebat’s son Jeroboam, are they not?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon reigned for 40 years in Jerusalem over all of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon died, as had his ancestors, and his son Rehoboam reigned in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam traveled to Shechem, because all of Israel went there to install him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nebat’s son Jeroboam heard about it in Egypt, where he had fled to get away from Solomon the king. Jeroboam returned from Egypt
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: after being summoned. When Jeroboam and all of Israel arrived, they spoke to Rehoboam,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Your father made our burdens unbearable. Therefore you must lighten your father’s requirements and his heavy burden that he placed on us, and we’ll serve you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Come back again in three days,” Rehoboam told them. So the people left
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: while King Rehoboam conferred with his advisors who had worked with his father Solomon during his administration. He asked them, “What is your advice as to what response I should return to these people?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In reply, they told him, “If you will be kind to this people, please them, and speak appropriately to them with kind words, they’ll serve you forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Rehoboam ignored the counsel that his elder advisors had given him. Instead, he consulted the younger men who had grown up with him and worked for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As a result, he asked them, “What’s your advice, so we can give an answer to these people who have asked me, ‘Please lighten the burden that your father put on us’?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what you should tell the people who asked you: ‘Your father made our burden heavy, but you must make it lighter for us!’” the young men who had grown up with Rehoboam replied. “Tell them ‘My little finger will be thicker than my father’s whole body!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Not only that, but since my father loaded you down heavily, I’m going to add to that burden. If my father disciplined you with whips, I’m going to do so with scorpions!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeroboam and all the people went back to Rehoboam on the third day, just as they had been directed when the king said, “Come back again in three days.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king answered them strictly and ignored the counsel of his elders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, Rehoboam spoke to them along the lines of what the younger men suggested. He told them, “My father burdened you heavily, but I will add to that burden. If my father disciplined you with whips, I will, too—with scorpions!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king would not listen to the people because the turn of events was from God, so that the Lord might fulfill his prediction that he spoke through Nebat’s son Ahijah the Shilonite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of Israel—since the king wasn’t going to listen to them—the people responded to the king, “What’s the point in following David? We have no inheritance in the descendants of Jesse. Let’s go home, Israel! David, take care of your own household!” So all of Israel left for home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so Rehoboam ruled over the Israelis who lived in the cities of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Rehoboam sent Hadoram, who was in charge of conscripted labor, but the Israelis stoned him to death, and King Rehoboam had to jump in his chariot and flee back in a hurry to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That’s how Israel came to be in rebellion against David’s dynasty to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Rehoboam returned to Jerusalem, he gathered together 180,000 specially chosen soldiers from the households of Judah and Benjamin to fight against Israel and restore the kingdom to Rehoboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But a message from the Lord came to Shemaiah, a man of God:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tell Solomon’s son Rehoboam, king of Judah and all of Israel in Judah and Benjamin:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what the Lord says: “You are not to fight or even to approach your relatives in battle. Every soldier is to return to his own home, for this development comes from me.”’” So they listened to what the Lord had to say and called off their attack on Jeroboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam continued to live in Jerusalem and built defensive fortification cities throughout Judah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: including Bethlehem, Etam, Tekoa,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Beth-zur, Soco, Adullam,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gath, Mareshah, Ziph,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adoraim, Lachish, Azekah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zorah, Aijalon, and Hebron. These were all fortified cities throughout Judah and Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also strengthened the fortified cities, assigned officers to them, and stockpiled food, oil, and wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also stockpiled shields and spears in every city and fortified them greatly to secure his rule over Judah and Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests and descendants of Levi throughout Israel also supported him in their districts,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because the descendants of Levi left their pasture lands and their property to live in Judah and Jerusalem, since Jeroboam and his sons had excluded them from participating in priestly services to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam had appointed his own priests to serve at the high places and to serve the satyrs and calves that he had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As a result, anyone from all of the tribes of Israel who was determined to seek the Lord God of Israel followed the descendants of Levi to Jerusalem so they could sacrifice to the Lord God of their ancestors,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they continued to strengthen the kingdom of Judah, supporting Solomon’s son Rehoboam for three years, by living the way David and Solomon did for three years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam married Mahalath, the daughter of David’s son Jerimoth, along with Abihail, the daughter of Jesse’s son Eliab,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: who bore him these sons: Jeush, Shemariah, and Zaham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this he married Absalom’s daughter Maacah, who bore him Abijah, Attai, Ziza, and Shelomith.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam loved Absalom’s daughter Maacah more than he did all of his wives and mistresses. (He married eighteen wives and 60 concubines, fathering 28 sons and 60 daughters.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, Rehoboam appointed Abijah, his son from Maacah, as senior family leader among his brothers, since he intended to establish Abijah as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam was wise to distribute some of his children throughout all of the territories of Judah and Benjamin, placing them in all of the fortified cities. He allotted them abundant supplies of food and sought many wives for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the height of his power, after he had consolidated his rule, Rehoboam abandoned the Lord’s Law, along with all of Israel with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because he had been unfaithful to the Lord, during the fifth year of King Rehoboam’s reign, King Shishak of Egypt attacked Jerusalem
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: with 1,200 chariots and 60,000 cavalry. The Lubim, Sukkiim, and the Ethiopians who invaded from Egypt with Shishak were innumerable.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shishak captured the fortified cities of Judah and invaded as far as Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Right then, Shemaiah the prophet approached Rehoboam and the princes of Judah who had gathered together in Jerusalem because of Shishak, and he told them, “This is what the Lord says: ‘You abandoned me, so I’ve abandoned you to Shishak.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In response, the princes of Israel and the king humbled themselves and declared, “The Lord is righteous.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord observed that they had humbled themselves, the Lord spoke to Shemaiah, “They have humbled themselves, so I won’t destroy them. Instead, I’ll grant them some deliverance by not pouring out my indignation on Jerusalem, using Shishak to do it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, they will become his slaves so they may learn to differentiate between what it means to serve me and to serve the kingdoms of these nations.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Shishak of Egypt invaded Jerusalem and looted the treasure stores in the Lord’s Temple and in the royal palace. He took everything, including the golden shields that Solomon had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, King Rehoboam made shields out of bronze to take their place, committing them to the care and custody of the commanders of those who guarded the entrance to the royal palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As often as the king entered the Lord’s Temple, the guards came and transported the shields to the Temple and then brought them back to the guard’s quarters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he had humbled himself, the Lord stopped being angry with him, and did not destroy Rehoboam completely. Furthermore, conditions became good in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Rehoboam consolidated his reign in Jerusalem. Rehoboam was 41 years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city that that Lord had chosen from all the tribes of Israel in which to establish his name. Rehoboam’s mother was Naamah from Ammon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He practiced evil by not setting his heart to seek the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Rehoboam’s accomplishments, from first to last, are written in the records of Shemaiah the prophet and of Iddo the seer, enrolled by genealogy, are they not?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, Rehoboam died, as had his ancestors, and his son Abijah became king to replace him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the eighteenth year of the reign of King Jeroboam, Abijah became king over Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He reigned for three years in Jerusalem. His mother was Uriel’s daughter Micaiah from Gibeah.
A war started between Abijah and Jeroboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abijah started the battle with an army of 400,000 specially chosen valiant soldiers, but Jeroboam opposed him with 800,000 specially chosen valiant soldiers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Abijah stood on Mount Zemaraim in the hill country of Ephraim and announced:
“Listen to me, Jeroboam and Israel!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t you know that the Lord God of Israel assigned the kingship over Israel to David and his descendants forever by a salt covenant?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even so, Nebat’s son Jeroboam, who used to serve David’s son Solomon, rose in rebellion against his own master!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Useless troublemakers soon gathered around him, who turned out to be too strong for Rehoboam, because he was young, timid, and unable to withstand them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So now you think you’ll be able to withstand the Lord’s kingdom as controlled by David’s descendants, just because you have a large crown and have brought with you the golden calves that Jeroboam made for you as gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Haven’t you already driven away the Lord’s priests, the descendants of Aaron and the descendants of Levi? Haven’t you established your own priests like the people of other lands?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now as far as we’re concerned, the Lord is our God, and we haven’t abandoned him. The descendants of Aaron are ministering to the Lord as priests, and the descendants of Levi continue their work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every morning and evening, they’re offering burnt offerings and fragrant incense to the Lord, the showbread is set out on the pure table, and they take care of the golden lamp stand so its lamps can continue to burn every evening. We continue to be faithful over what the Lord our God entrusted to us, but you have abandoned him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now listen! God is with us to lead us, and his priests are about to sound their battle trumpets against you. Descendants of Israel, don’t fight against the Lord God of your ancestors, because you won’t succeed!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jeroboam had sent an ambush to attack from the rear, so Israel was in front of Judah, with the ambush set in place behind them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the army of Judah turned around to look, they were being attacked from both front and rear, so they cried out to the Lord while the priests sounded their trumpets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the army of Judah sounded a war cry, and God routed Jeroboam and the entire army of Israel in front of Abijah and Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the descendants of Israel ran away from the army of Judah, God handed them over to the army of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abijah and his army defeated them in a tremendous slaughter that resulted in 500,000 special forces from Israel being slain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so the descendants of Israel were defeated at that time. The descendants of Judah were victorious because they trusted in the Lord God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this Abijah pursued Jeroboam and captured Bethel and its villages, Jeshanah and its villages, and Ephron and its villages.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam never recovered his strength for the rest of Abijah’s life. The Lord struck Jeroboam, and he died,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but Abijah continued to grow more powerful. He took fourteen wives for himself and fathered 22 sons and sixteen daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of Abijah’s accomplishments, his lifestyle and his memoirs are recorded in the Midrash of the Prophet Iddo.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abijah died, as had his ancestors, and he was buried in the City of David. Abijah’s son Asa reigned in his place, and during his lifetime the land enjoyed rest for ten years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa practiced what the Lord his God considered to be right
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: by removing the foreign altars and high places, tearing down the sacred pillars, cutting down the Asherim, and
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: commanding Judah to seek the Lord God of their ancestors and to keep the Law and the commandments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also removed the high places and incense altars from all of the cities of Judah. As a result, the kingdom enjoyed rest under Asa’s leadership.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa built fortified cities throughout Judah while the land lay undisturbed, because the Lord had given him peace so that no one went to war against him during those years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had told Judah, “Let’s build up these cities, surrounding them with walls, towers, gates, and bars. The land still belongs to us, because we have kept on seeking the Lord our God. We have sought him out, and he has given us rest all around us.” So the people built and prospered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa kept a standing army of 300,000 soldiers from Judah equipped with large shields and spears, as well as 280,000 soldiers from Benjamin, also bearing shields and wielding bows. All of them were valiant soldiers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sometime later, Zerah the Ethiopian went to war against him at Mareshah with an army of one million troops and 300 chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa went out to engage him in battle, and they drew up their battle lines at Mareshah in the Zephathah Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa cried out to the Lord his God, telling him, “Lord, there is no one except for you to help between the powerful and the weak. So help us, Lord God, because we’re depending on you and have come against this vast group in your name. Lord, you are our God. Let no mere mortal man defeat you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord defeated the Ethiopians right in front of Asa and Judah, and the Ethiopians ran away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa and his army pursued the Ethiopians as far as Gerar. So many Ethiopians died that their army could not recover, because it had been shattered in the Lord’s presence and in the presence of his army. The Israelis carried off a lot of plunder, too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They attacked all the cities that surrounded Gerar, because fear of the Lord had overwhelmed them. The Israelis spoiled all the cities, because there was a lot to plunder in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also attacked the tents of those who owned livestock and carried off lots of sheep and camels. Then they returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, the Spirit of God came to rest on Oded’s son Azariah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
so he went out to meet Asa and rebuked him:
“Listen to me, Asa, Judah, and Benjamin! The Lord is with you when you are with him. If you seek him, he will allow you to find him, but if you abandon him, he will abandon you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel lived for years without the true God, priests to teach them, and the Law,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but they turned to the Lord God of Israel in their distress. When they sought him, he let them become reacquainted with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “During those days, it wasn’t safe for anyone to come and go, because many civil disturbances afflicted everyone who lived in the territories.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nation battled nation, and city fought city, because God was afflicting them all with every kind of distress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now as for you, be strong and never be discouraged, because there will be reward for your work.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Encouraged by what Oded’s son Azariah the prophet had said in his prophecy, Asa removed the detestable idols from throughout the entire territories of Judah and Benjamin, and from the cities that he had captured in the hill country of Ephraim. He repaired the Lord’s altar that stood in front of the vestibule of the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he gathered together all of Judah, Benjamin, and people from Ephraim, Manasseh, and Simeon who were living among them, since many people had defected to him from Israel when they learned that the Lord his God was with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They all assembled in Jerusalem during the third month of the fifteenth year of Asa’s reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They sacrificed to the Lord that day 700 oxen and 7,000 sheep from the spoil that they had brought with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also entered into a covenant to seek the Lord God of their ancestors with all their heart and soul,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they further agreed that whoever would refuse to seek the Lord God of Israel was to be executed, whether important or unimportant, man or woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also made a vow to the Lord with loud voices, shouting, trumpets, and horns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everybody in Judah was very glad to make their oath, because they had made their vow with all their heart and had sought him with all of their might, and they found him! The Lord also gave them rest in their surrounding lands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Asa removed his mother Maacah from her position as Queen Mother because she had made a detestable image dedicated to Asherah. He cut down his mother’s idol, crushed it, and burned it at the Kidron Brook.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, the high places were not removed from Israel, even though Asa’s heart was blameless all of his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa brought into God’s Temple the things that his father had dedicated, as well as his own dedicated gifts such as silver, gold, and temple service implements.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa experienced no more war until the end of the thirty-fifth year of his reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the thirty-sixth year of Asa’s reign, King Baasha of Israel invaded Judah and interdicted Ramah by building fortifications around it so no one could enter or leave to join King Asa of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Asa removed some silver and gold from the treasuries of the Lord’s Temple and from his royal palace and sent them to King Ben-hadad of Aram, who lived in Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Let’s make a treaty between you and me,” he said, “just like the one between my father and your father. Notice that I’ve sent you silver and gold to break your treaty with King Baasha of Israel, so he’ll retreat from his attack on me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Ben-hadad did just what King Asa had asked: he sent his commanding officers to attack the cities of Israel. They conquered Ijon, Dan, Bel-maim, and all of the storage centers in Naphtali.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Baasha learned of the attack, he withdrew from Ramah and stopped his interdiction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Asa brought his entire army of Judah to carry away the building stones and the timber that Baasha had been using to surround Ramah, and he used those materials to fortify Geba and Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Right about then, Hanani the seer came to King Asa of Judah and rebuked him. “Because you have put your trust in the king of Aram and have not relied on the Lord your God, the army of the king of Aram has escaped from your control.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Weren’t the Ethiopians and the Libyans a vast army with many chariots and cavalry? Yet because you relied on the Lord, he gave them into your control!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord’s eyes keep on roaming throughout the earth, looking for those whose hearts completely belong to him, so that he may strongly support them. But because you have acted foolishly in this, from now on you will have wars.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In response, Asa flew into a rage and locked up the seer in stocks in the palace prison because of what Hanani had told him. Asa also tortured some of the people of Israel at that time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the accomplishments of Asa from first to last are written in the Book of the Kings of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the thirty-ninth year of his reign, Asa suffered from a foot disease. Even though he suffered greatly, he never sought the Lord, but instead looked to doctors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As a result, in the forty-first year of his reign, Asa died, as had his ancestors,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he was buried in his own tomb that he had prepared for himself in the City of David. He was laid out on a bier that had been filled with various spices prepared by morticians, and the mourners built a massive bonfire to honor his memory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa’s son Jehoshaphat succeeded him as king, and he consolidated his authority over Israel
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: by placing troops in all of the fortified citadels through Judah and by establishing garrisons throughout the land of Judah and in the cities that his father Asa had captured.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord was with Jehoshaphat because he followed the example set during his ancestor David’s preliminary years by not pursuing the Baals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, Jehoshaphat sought the God of his ancestors and obeyed his commands, unlike Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore the Lord secured Jehoshaphat’s kingdom under his control, with all of Judah paying him tribute, and Jehoshaphat became very wealthy and greatly respected.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He remained committed to following the Lord, and he removed the high places and Asherah poles from Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the third year of his reign, Jehoshaphat sent his officials Ben-hail, Obadiah, Zechariah, Nethanel, and Micaiah to teach throughout the cities of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were accompanied by the descendants of Levi, including Shemaiah, Nethaniah, Zebadiah, Asahel, Shemiramoth, Jehonathan, Adonijah, Tobijah, and Tobadonijah. These descendants of Levi were accompanied by the priests Elishama and Jehoram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They taught throughout Judah from a copy of the Book of the Law of the Lord that they took with them as they passed through all the cities of Judah, teaching among all the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because they were afraid of the Lord, none of the kingdoms of the lands that surrounded Judah dared go to war against Jehoshaphat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the Philistines brought gifts and silver as tribute to Jehoshaphat, and Arabians brought him flocks of 7,700 rams and 7,700 male goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As a result, Jehoshaphat grew more and more powerful, and built up fortresses and storage centers throughout Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He placed a large amount of supplies into storage throughout the cities of Judah and stationed soldiers—all of them valiant men—in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here’s how they were mustered, listed according to their ancestral houses and listed by commanders of thousands: Adnah commanded 300,000 elite forces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Near him was Johanan, commander of 280,000
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and next to him was Zichri’s son Amasiah, who had volunteered to serve the Lord. He commanded 200,000 elite forces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was also Eliada from Benjamin, himself a valiant soldier. He was accompanied by 200,000 expert archers bearing shields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Near him was Jehozabad, who was accompanied by 180,000 soldiers equipped for warfare.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These men served the king, and there were others whom the king garrisoned inside fortified cities throughout all of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Jehoshaphat had become wealthy and was enjoying abundant honor, he allied himself to Ahab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After a few years, he visited Ahab in Samaria. Ahab slaughtered lots of sheep and oxen for him, and the people who were with him persuaded Jehoshaphat to attack Ramoth-gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
King Ahab of Israel asked King Jehoshaphat of Judah, “Will you join me in attacking Ramoth-gilead?”
“I’m with you,” Jehoshaphat replied. “and my army is with you. We’ll join you in the battle.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But then Jehoshaphat asked the king of Israel, “Please ask for a message from the Lord, first.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the king of Israel gathered together 400 prophets and asked them, “Should we go attack Ramoth-gilead, or should I call off the attack?”
“Go attack them,” they all said, “because God will drop them right in the king’s hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jehoshaphat asked, “Isn’t there a prophet of the Lord left here that we could talk to?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“There is still one man left by whom we could ask the Lord what to do,” the king of Israel replied to Jehoshaphat, “but I hate him because he won’t prophesy anything good about me. Instead, he always prophesies evil. He is Imla’s son Micaiah.”
But Jehoshaphat rebuked Ahab, “Kings should never talk like that.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, the king of Israel called an officer and ordered him, “Bring me Imla’s son Micaiah quickly.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the king of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah were each sitting on their own thrones, arrayed in their robes, and sitting on the threshing floor at the entrance to the city gate of Samaria, and all of the prophets were prophesying in front of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Chenaanah’s son Zedekiah made iron horns for himself and told them, “This is what the Lord says, ‘With these horns you are to gore the Arameans until they are eliminated!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the other prophets were saying similar things, like “Go up to Ramoth-gilead and you will be successful, because the Lord will hand it over to the king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the messenger who had gone off to summon Micaiah advised him, “Look, everything that the other prophets were saying has been unanimously favorable to the king. So please, cooperate with them and speak favorably.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As the Lord lives,” Micaiah replied, “I’ll say what my God tells me to say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Micaiah approached the king, the king asked him, “Micaiah, should we go to war against Ramoth-gilead, or should I not?”
“Go to war,” Micaiah replied, “and you will be successful, because the Lord will hand it over to the king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he heard this, the king asked him, “How many times do I have to ask you? Tell me nothing but the truth, and do it in the name of the Lord!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And so Micaiah replied:
“I saw all of Israel
    scattered on the mountains
        like sheep without a shepherd.
And the Lord told me,
    ‘These have no master,
        so let them each return to his own home in peace.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Israel told Jehoshaphat, “Didn’t I tell you that he wouldn’t prophesy anything good about me, but only evil?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Micaiah responded, “Therefore, listen to what the Lord has to say. I saw the Lord, sitting on his throne, and the entire Heavenly Army was surrounding him on his right hand and on his left hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Lord asked, ‘Who will tempt King Ahab of Israel to attack Ramoth-gilead, so that he will die there?’ And one was saying one thing and one was saying another.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But then a spirit approached, stood in front of the Lord, and said, ‘I will entice him.’
“And the Lord asked him, ‘How?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“‘I will go,’ he announced, ‘and I will be a deceiving spirit in the mouth of all of his prophets!’
“So the Lord said, ‘You’re just the one to deceive him. You will be successful. Go and do it.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now therefore, listen! The Lord has placed a lying spirit in the mouth of all of these prophets of yours, because the Lord has determined to bring disaster upon you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As if on cue, Chenaanah’s son Zedekiah approached Micaiah and struck him on the cheek. Then he asked him, “How did the Spirit of the Lord move from me to speak to you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah replied, “You’ll learn the answer to that question when the day comes that you run away to hide yourself in a closet!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Israel ordered, “Take Micaiah and place him in the custody of Amon, the city governor. Hand him over to Joash, the king’s son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give him this order: ‘Place him in prison on survival rations only until I come back safely.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If you return alive,” Micaiah responded, “then the Lord has not spoken by me.” Then he added, “Listen, everybody!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah both attacked Ramoth-gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel suggested to Jehoshaphat, “I’ll go into battle in disguise, but you keep your royal uniform on.” So the king of Israel disguised himself and they both went into the battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the king of Aram had issued these orders to his chariot commanders: “Don’t attack unimportant soldiers or ranking officers. Go after only the king of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when the chariot commanders observed Jehoshaphat, they said by mistake, “It’s the king of Israel!” and they turned aside to attack him. But Jehoshaphat cried out to the Lord, who helped him, and God diverted them from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the chariot commanders saw that their target was not the king of Israel, they stopped pursuing him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, somebody drew his bow and struck the king of Israel at a weak spot where his armor plates joined, so he instructed his chariot driver, “Turn around and take me out of the battle, because I’ve been severely wounded.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The battle continued on for the rest of the day while the king of Israel propped himself up in front of the Arameans until the sun set, at which time he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, King Jehoshaphat of Judah returned safely to his palace in Jerusalem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: where Hanani’s son Jehu, the seer, went out to meet him. He asked king Jehoshaphat, “Should you be helping those who are wicked, yes or no? Should you love those who hate the Lord? Wrath is headed your way directly from the Lord because of this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, a few good things have been found in you, in that you have removed the Asheroth from the land and you have disciplined yourself to seek God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat continued to live in Jerusalem, but he travelled again throughout the people from Beer-sheba to Mount Ephraim, bringing them back to the Lord God of their ancestors
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and appointing judges throughout the land in all of the walled cities of Judah, city by city. He issued this reminder to the judges:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Pay careful attention to your duties, because you are judging not only for the sake of human beings but also for the Lord —and he is present with you as you make your rulings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So let the fear of the Lord rest upon you, be on your guard, and act carefully, because with the Lord our God there is neither injustice, nor partiality, nor bribery.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Jerusalem, Jehoshaphat also appointed certain descendants of Levi, priests, and family leaders of Israel to render verdicts for the Lord and to decide difficult cases. Their offices were in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He issued this reminder to them:
“You are to carry out your duties in the fear of the Lord, serving him faithfully with your whole heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No matter what case comes before you from your fellow citizens who live in their own cities, whether it’s a dispute between blood relatives or a dispute regarding the Law and the commands, statutes, or verdicts, you are to warn the parties so that they do not become guilty in the Lord’s presence and so that anger does not come upon you and your fellow citizens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take notice, please, that Amariah the Chief Priest is presiding over all cases that pertain to the Lord, Ishmael’s son Zebadiah is presiding as ruler of the household of Judah with respect to all cases that pertain to the national government, and the descendants of Levi will preside over your other civil cases. Serve courageously, and the Lord will be with the upright.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sometime after these events, the Moabites and the Ammonites, accompanied by some other descendants of Ammon, attacked Jehoshaphat and started a war.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat’s military advisors came and informed him, “We’ve been attacked by a vast invasion force from Aram, beyond the Dead Sea. Be advised—they’ve already reached Hazazon-tamar, also known as En-gedi.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In mounting fear, Jehoshaphat devoted himself to seek the Lord. He proclaimed a period of fasting throughout all of the territory of Judah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the tribe of Judah assembled together to seek the Lord. People came from all of the cities of Judah to seek the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat stood among the assembly of Judah and Jerusalem in the Lord’s Temple in the vicinity of the new court
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and said:
“Lord God of our ancestors, you are the God who lives in heaven, are you not? You rule over all the kingdoms of the nations, don’t you? In your own hands you grasp both strength and power, don’t you? As a result, no one can oppose you, can they?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are our God, who expelled the former inhabitants of this land right in front of our people Israel, aren’t you? Then you gave it to your friend Abraham’s descendant forever, didn’t you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They lived in it and have built there a sanctuary for your name, where they said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If evil comes upon us, such as war as punishment, disease, or famine and we stand in your presence in this Temple (because your Name is in this Temple) and cry out to you in our distress, then you will hear and deliver.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now therefore look! The Ammonites, the Moabites, and the inhabitants of Mount Seir, whom you would not permit Israel to attack when they arrived from the land of Egypt—since they turned away from them and did not eliminate them—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look how they’re rewarding us! They’re coming to drive us from your property that you gave us to be our inheritance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Our God, you are going to punish them, aren’t you? We have no strength to face this vast multitude that has come against us, nor do we know what to do, except that our eyes are on you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of Judah was standing in the Lord’s presence, along with their little babies, their wives, and their children.
verses.speaker: Narrator
