verses.text: Then the Spirit of the Lord came upon Zechariah’s son Jahaziel, the son of Benaiah, the son of Jeiel, the son of Mattaniah, a descendant of Levi from the descendants of Asaph in the middle of the assembly, and he said:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Pay attention, everyone in Judah, in Jerusalem, and you, too, King Jehoshaphat! This is what the Lord says to you: ‘Stop being afraid, and stop being discouraged because of this vast invasion force, because the battle doesn’t belong to you, but to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tomorrow you are to go down to attack them. Pay attention, now—they’ll be coming up near the ascent of Ziz. You’ll find them at the end of the valley that looks out over the Jeruel wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You won’t be fighting in this battle. Take your stand, but stand still, and watch the Lord’s salvation on your behalf, Judah and Jerusalem! Never fear and never be discouraged. Go out to face them tomorrow, since the Lord is with you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat bowed down with his face to the ground, and all the assembled inhabitants of Judah and Jerusalem fell face down in the Lord’s presence and worshipped the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Descendants of Levi from the descendants of Kohath and from the descendants of Korah stood up to praise the Lord God of Israel in a very loud voice that ascended to heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The army got up early the next morning and headed out into the wilderness of Tekoa. Jehoshaphat stood up and addressed them. “Listen to me, you inhabitants of Judah and Jerusalem,” he said. “Have faith in the Lord your God and you’ll be established! Have faith in his prophets and you’ll succeed!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
After he had consulted with the people, Jehoshaphat appointed some choir members to sing to the Lord and to praise him in sacred splendor as they marched out in front of the armed forces. They kept saying
“Give thanks to the Lord,
    because his gracious love is eternal!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Right on time, as they began to sing and praise, the Lord ambushed the Ammonites, Moabites, and the inhabitants of Mount Seir who had attacked Judah, and they were defeated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ammonites and Moabites attacked the inhabitants of Mount Seir, destroying them, and after they had finished with the inhabitants of Mount Seir, they worked on destroying one another!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the army of Judah arrived at the remotest watchtower in the wilderness, they looked around at the invasion force, and to their surprise, there were dead bodies lying all around on the ground—not one had escaped!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later on, when Jehoshaphat and his army arrived to collect the spoils of war, they discovered there were far more goods, garments, and other valuable items to collect than they could carry off in a single day. There was so much material that it took three days to finish their collection efforts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three days later, they assembled together in the Beracah Valley, where they blessed the Lord, which is why the name of that place is called Beracah Valley to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they all returned with joy to Jerusalem, every soldier from Judah and Jerusalem, with Jehoshaphat at the head of the procession, because the Lord had made them rejoice over their enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They proceeded directly to the Lord’s Temple, carrying lyres, harps, and trumpets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fear of God seized all of the kingdoms in the surrounding territories when they heard that the Lord had battled Israel’s enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As a result, Jehoshaphat’s kingdom enjoyed peace, because his God had provided rest for him all around.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat reigned over Judah, having become king at the age of 35. He reigned in Jerusalem for 25 years. His mother’s name was Azubah, the daughter of Shilhi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He followed the example of his father Asa and never departed from it, practicing what the Lord considered to be right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, the high places were not removed, since the people had not yet directed their hearts to the God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of Jehoshaphat’s accomplishments, from first to last, are recorded in the annals of Hanani’s son Jehu, which appears in the Book of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sometime later, King Jehoshaphat of Judah entered into a military alliance with King Ahaziah of Israel, acting wickedly by doing so.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also agreed with King Ahaziah to build ships to sail toward Tarshish, which they built in Ezion-geber.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Dodavahu’s son Eliezer from Mareshah prophesied in opposition to Jehoshaphat, “Because you have entered into an alliance with Ahaziah, the Lord has destroyed your efforts.” So the ships were destroyed and were never able to sail for Tarshish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat died, as had his ancestors, and was buried in the City of David alongside his ancestors. His son Jehoram became king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat’s sons, Jehoram’s brothers, included Azariah, Jehiel, Zechariah, Azariah, Michael, and Shephatiah. All of these were sons of Jehoshaphat, king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their father gave them many gifts made of silver, and gold, as well as valuable things, along with fortified cities in Judah, but he passed the kingdom to Jehoram because Jehoram was his firstborn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after Jehoram had assumed the throne and consolidated his rule over his father’s kingdom, he executed all of his brothers, along with some of the rulers of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoram was 32 years old when he became king, and he reigned for eight years in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He lived like the kings of Israel, following the example of Ahab’s dynasty, since he had married Ahab’s daughter, and he practiced what the Lord considered to be evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, the Lord was unwilling to destroy David’s dynasty because of the covenant that he had made with David, especially since he had promised to give him and to his sons the reigning presence of an heir forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, Edom revolted against Judah’s rule and set up their own king to rule them during Jehoram’s reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jehoram invaded Edom with his commanders and his chariots by night and killed the Edomites who had surrounded him and his chariot commanders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Edom remains in revolt against Judah to this day. Libnah revolted against Jehoram’s rule, too, because he had abandoned the Lord God of his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition to all of this, he built high places in the mountains of Judah, led the inhabitants of Jerusalem into cultic sexual immorality, and made Judah go astray.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
After this, a letter arrived from Elijah the prophet. It said:
“This is what the Lord God of your ancestor David says: ‘You haven’t lived like your father Jehoshaphat and like King Asa of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, you have lived like the kings of Israel by causing Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem to commit cultic sexual immorality—just like Ahab’s dynasty did! And you’ve killed your brothers who were better than you—your own father’s dynasty!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look what’s going to happen! The Lord is going to strike your people, your children, your wives, and everything you own with a massive tragedy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And as for you, you will suffer from a serious disease of your bowels. Eventually, day-by-day you will excrete your own bowels because of this disease.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord also provoked the attitude of the Philistines and the Arabs who bordered the Ethiopians against Jehoram,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they attacked Judah, invading it and carried off everything he owned in his royal palace, along with all of his sons and wives except for his youngest son Jehoahaz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all of this happened, the Lord struck him in his bowels with an incurable illness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In due course, as time passed, two years later his bowels came out because of his sickness and he died in agony. His people lit no memorial bonfire for him as they had done for his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoram was 32 years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for eight years. He left this earth—to nobody’s regret—and they buried him in the City of David, but not in the tombs of the kings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The residents of Jerusalem made Jehoram’s son Ahaziah king in his place after the raiding party that had invaded the city with the Arabs had killed all of the older sons. That’s how Jehoram’s son Ahaziah became king of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaziah was 22 years old when he became king, and he reigned for one year in Jerusalem. His mother was Athaliah, Omri’s granddaughter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He followed the example of Ahab’s dynasty because his mother gave him evil counsel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he practiced what the Lord considered to be evil, just like Ahab’s dynasty had done, because after his father died, he was given advice that resulted in his destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He followed their counsel and accompanied Ahab’s son Joram, king of Israel, to wage war against King Hazael of Aram at Ramoth-gilead. But the Arameans wounded Joram,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so he returned to Jezreel to recover from the wounds that he had received at Ramah in the battle against King Hazael of Aram. King Ahaziah of Judah, Jehoram’s son, went to visit Ahab’s son Joram, because he was wounded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God used Ahaziah’s visit to Joram to destroy Ahaziah. As soon as he arrived, Ahaziah went out with Joram to attack Nimshi’s son Jehu, whom the Lord had appointed to eliminate Ahab’s dynasty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And that’s exactly what happened. While Jehu was punishing Ahab’s dynasty, he located the princes of Judah and the sons of Ahaziah’s brothers who were ministering to Ahaziah, and he put them to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehu also searched for Ahaziah, had him apprehended while Ahaziah was hiding out in Samaria, and had Ahaziah brought to him. Jehu had Ahaziah executed and buried. It was said of Jehu, “He is the son of Jehoshaphat, who sought the Lord with all of his heart.” As a result, there was no one left in the household of Ahaziah strong enough to reign in the kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as Ahaziah’s mother Athaliah learned that her son had died, she set out to destroy the entire royal family of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, the king’s daughter Jehoshabeath took Ahaziah’s son Joash away from the king’s children who were about to be assassinated and hid him and his nurse in a bedroom. That’s how King Jehoram’s daughter Jehoshabeath, who was also the priest Jehoiada’s wife and Ahaziah’s sister, hid him from Athaliah. As a result, she was not able to kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joash remained with them for six years, hidden in God’s Temple while Athaliah reigned over the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seven years later, Jehoiada mustered up some courage and made a deal with the officers who commanded units of hundreds of soldiers, including Jehoram’s son Azariah, Jehochanan’s son Ishmael, Obed’s son Azariah, Adaiah’s son Maaseiah, and Zichri’s son Elishaphat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They traveled throughout Judah and gathered together the descendants of Levi from all the cities of Judah, along with the Israeli family leaders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Everybody went to Jerusalem, and the whole group made a covenant with the king in God’s Temple, where Jehoiada addressed them:
“Look! The king’s son is going to rule, just as the Lord promised David’s descendants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So here’s what you’ll need to do: One third of you priests and descendants of Levi who are on duty during the Sabbath will serve as guards at the temple gates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Another third of you priests and descendants of Levi will take your places in the royal palace, while another third of you priests and descendants of Levi will stand near the Foundation Gate. The rest of you will remain in the courtyard of the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nobody is to enter the Lord’s Temple except for the priests and descendants of Levi who are on duty. They may enter because they are ceremonially holy, but all the rest of the people must observe the Lord’s instructions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Levi will surround the king, brandishing weapons in their hands, and anybody who enters the Temple will be killed. Stay near the king wherever he enters and leaves.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What Jehoiada the priest ordered is precisely what the descendants of Levi and all of Judah did. Each of them took the men who were on duty on the Sabbath as well as those who were off duty. Jehoiada the priest did not release the divisions from service,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Jehoiada the priest issued the spears and shields that King David had placed in storage in God’s Temple to the officers in charge of the units of hundreds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He set the rest of the people to serve as guards for the king, and each one brandished weapons in his hand, from the south side of the Temple to the north side of the Temple, around the altar, and surrounding the palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he brought out the king’s son, put a crown on him, and presented him with the Testimony,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Athaliah heard all the commotion of the people running around and praising the king, she went straight to the Lord’s Temple to confront the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She looked around, and there was the king, standing by his pillar at the gate, accompanied by officers and trumpeters who stood beside the king, along with all the people of the land rejoicing and sounding trumpets while singers lead the celebration with their musical instruments. Athaliah tore her robes and yelled “Treason! Treason!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jehoiada the priest summoned the captains of hundreds who had been appointed in charge over the army and ordered them, “Bring her out between the ranks, and execute anyone who follows her.” The priest also told them, “Don’t execute her in the Lord’s Temple.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they arrested her when she arrived at the entrance to the Horse Gate near the royal palace, and then they executed her there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Jehoiada drew up a covenant between himself as an individual with all the people, and between himself as king, that they would be the Lord’s people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the people went to the temple of Baal, broke its altars and idols to pieces, and executed Mattan, the priest of Baal, in front of the altars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiada also placed the offices of the Lord’s Temple under the authority of the Levitical priests whom David had assigned over the Lord’s Temple, just as is required by the Law of Moses, to offer the Lord’s burnt offerings with joy and singing, just as David had ordered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiada also stationed inspectors at the Lord’s Temple so that no one would enter who was ritually unclean in any manner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also took the captains of hundreds, the nobles, the people’s governors, and all the people of the land, and they all marched with the king from the Lord’s Temple through the upper gate to the royal palace, where they installed the king on his royal throne.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There all of the people of the land rejoiced and the city stayed quiet, because they had executed Athaliah with a sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joash was seven years old when he began his reign, and he reigned forty years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Zibiah. She was from Beer-sheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joash practiced what the Lord considered to be right during the lifetime of Jehoiada the priest,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: who found two wives for him, so he fathered sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later on, Joash decided to rebuild the Lord’s Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so he assembled the priests and descendants of Levi and ordered them, “Go throughout the cities of Judah and take up a collection from all of Israel for the annual upkeep of the Temple of your God. And make sure that you act quickly.” But the descendants of Levi did not act quickly,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so the king summoned Jehoiada the chief priest and asked him, “Why haven’t you required the descendants of Levi to bring from Judah and Jerusalem the tax levied by Moses, the Lord’s servant, and the assembly of Israel for the Tent of Testimony?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because that wicked woman Athaliah’s family members had broken into the Temple of God and used the consecrated implements of the Lord’s Temple for service to the Baals,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the king issued an order and a chest was made and set outside the entrance gate to the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A public notice was sent throughout Judah and Jerusalem to bring in the tax that Moses the servant of the Lord had levied on Israel when they were in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the princes and all the people gladly brought their tax and placed it into the chest until they had completed paying the tax.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever the chest was brought to the king’s officials by the descendants of Levi, the royal secretary and the chief priest’s designated officer would come, empty the chest, and take it back to its place. They did this day after day until they had collected a large amount of cash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Both the king and Jehoiada paid the money to those who were working to maintain the service of the Lord’s Temple, and they, in turn, hired masons and carpenters to restore the Lord’s Temple. Iron and bronze workers also were brought in to repair the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As a result, the workmen did their labor, and the repair work progressed steadily under their supervision, and they restored God’s Temple back to what it should be, and strengthened it, too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had completed the work, they brought what was left of the money to the king and to Jehoiada, and it was used to cast utensils for the Lord’s Temple that were to be utilized for daily service and for burnt offerings, for incense vessels, and for both gold and silver vessels. Burnt offerings were offered on a regular basis in the Lord’s Temple throughout Jehoiada’s lifetime.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eventually, Jehoiada grew old and died at the age of 130 years, after having lived a full life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was buried in the City of David among the graves of the kings, because he had accomplished many good things in Israel on behalf of God and his Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after Jehoiada had died, officials from Judah came, bowed down to the king, and the king listened to what they had to say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They abandoned the Lord’s Temple and the God of their fathers, and they served Asherim and idols. As a result this guilt of theirs resulted in wrath coming upon Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, God sent prophets among them to bring them back to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jehoiada the priest’s son Zechariah was clothed by the Spirit of God, and he stood above the people and told them, “This is what God has to say: ‘Why are you breaking the Lord’s commandments. You’ll never be successful! Because you have abandoned the Lord, he has abandoned you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people conspired against him, and at the direct orders of the king they stoned him to death in the courtyard of the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is how King Joash failed to remember the kindness that Zechariah’s father Jehoiada had shown him: he killed his son. As he lay dying, Zechariah cried out, “May the Lord watch this and avenge.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of that year, the Aramean army attacked Joash. They invaded Judah and Jerusalem, destroyed every senior official among the people, and sent all of their possessions to the king of Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Aramean army attacked with only a small force, but the Lord delivered a much larger army into their control because Judah had abandoned the Lord God of their ancestors. And so the Aramean army carried out God’s judgment on Joash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the Arameans left him very sick, Joash’s own servants conspired against him because Joash had murdered Jehoiada the priest’s son, and they killed him on his sick bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The conspirators included Shimeath the Ammonite’s son Zabad and Shimrith the Moabite’s son Jehozabad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Records concerning his sons, the various prophetic statements rebuking him, and records of the reconstruction work on God’s Temple are written in the Midrash of the Book of the Kings. Joash’s son Amaziah reigned in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amaziah began his reign at the age of 25 years, and he reigned 29 years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jehoaddan. She was from Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He practiced what the Lord considered to be right, but not with a perfect heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as he had consolidated his royal authority, he executed the servants who had killed his father, the king,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but he did not execute their children in obedience to what is written in the Law, the writings of Moses, where the Lord commanded, “Fathers are not to die because of what their children do, nor are children to die because of what their fathers do, but each person is to die for his own sins.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amaziah gathered Judah together and organized them according to their ancestral households under commanders of thousands and hundreds throughout Judah and Benjamin. He then mustered an army from those who were 20 years old and older. He discovered that there were 300,000 elite soldiers qualified for war duty and capable of handling spears and shields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also hired 100,000 elite forces from Israel, paying 100 talents of silver for their services.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man came from God and warned him, “Your majesty, don’t let the army of Israel accompany you into battle, because the Lord isn’t with any of the descendants of Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you do go, strengthen yourself for war. Do you think God will throw you down before the enemy, since God has the power both to help or to overthrow?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Amaziah asked the man of God, “What are we to do about the 100 talents that I have paid to the army of Israel?”
The man of God answered, “The Lord has a lot more than that to give you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Amaziah sent the troops home who had arrived from Ephraim. They flew into a rage against Judah but left for home very angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Amaziah encouraged himself and led his army out to the Salt Valley to kill 10,000 soldiers from Seir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The army of Judah captured another 10,000 prisoners and took them to the top of a cliff and threw them down from there where they all were dashed to pieces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the troops that Amaziah had sent home from the battle raided the cities of Judah from Samaria to Beth-horon, killing 3,000 people and taking a large amount of war booty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, Amaziah returned from slaughtering the Edomites, but he brought back the gods that had belonged to the men of Seir, set them up as his own gods, worshipped them, and sacrificed offerings to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As a result, the Lord became angry with Amaziah and sent a prophet to him, who asked him, “Why did you seek the gods of a people who were unable to deliver their own nation from you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But even while the prophet was speaking, the king asked him, “Did we appoint you to be a royal counselor? Stop! Why should you be struck down?”
So the prophet stopped speaking, but he also said, “I know God has determined to destroy you, because you’ve done all this and ignored my counsel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, King Amaziah of Judah sought some advice and then challenged Jehoahaz’ son King Joash of Israel, the grandson of Jehu, telling him, “Come out and let’s fight each other!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But King Joash of Israel replied to King Amaziah of Judah, “There once was a thorn bush in Lebanon that sent an invitation to the cedar of Lebanon that read ‘Give your daughter to my son in marriage.’ Right about then, a wild animal in Lebanon passed by and trampled the thorn bush.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You claim you’ve defeated Edom, but you’re really only puffed up with arrogant boasting. So stay home. Why stir up trouble so you die, and the rest of Judah with you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Amaziah refused to listen, because the situation was being orchestrated by God in order to turn them over to the control of their enemies because they had pursued those Edomite gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Joash of Israel went out to battle against King Amaziah of Judah, and they fought at Beth-shemesh, which is part of Judah’s territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah was defeated by Israel, and every soldier ran home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Joash of Israel captured Joash’s son King Amaziah of Judah, the grandson of Ahaziah, at Beth-shemesh and brought him back to Jerusalem, where he broke down 400 cubits of the wall of Jerusalem from the Ephraim Gate to the Corner Gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He confiscated all the gold, silver, and utensils that he could find in the care of Obed-edom inside of God’s Temple and inside the royal palace. Then he took some hostages and returned to Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joash’s son Amaziah, king of Judah, lived for fifteen years after the death of Jehoahaz’ son Joash, king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of Amaziah’s accomplishments, from first to last, are recorded in the Book of the Kings of Judah and Israel, are they not?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the time that Amaziah abandoned his seeking the Lord, some people conspired against him in Jerusalem, so he ran away to Lachish, but they pursued him to Lachish and killed him there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought him back on horses and buried him with his ancestors in the city of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people of Judah made Uzziah king in place of his father Amaziah. Uzziah was sixteen years old at the time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He rebuilt Eloth and restored it to Judah after King Amaziah had been laid to rest with his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah was sixteen years old when he became king, and he reigned for 52 years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jecholiah. She was from Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He practiced what the Lord considered to be right, following the example set by his father Amaziah’s accomplishments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah kept on seeking God during the lifetime of Zechariah, who taught him how to fear God, and as long as he sought the Lord, God made him prosperous.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One time Uzziah went out and battled the Philistines. He tore down the walls of Gath, Jabneh, and Ashdod, and built cities in the Ashdod area among the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God helped Uzziah defeat the Philistines, the Arabians who lived in Gur-baal, and the Meunites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ammonites paid tribute to Uzziah, and his reputation extended as far as the border with Egypt as he became stronger and stronger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah also built towers in Jerusalem, at the Corner Gate, at the Valley Gate, and at the Angle and fortified them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also built watchtowers in the wilderness and had many cisterns hewed out, since he also possessed large herds, both in the Shephelah and in the midland plains. He had many farmers and vinedressers throughout the hills and fertile lands because he loved farming.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah kept a standing army, equipped for battle, garrisoned in divisions according to an organizational structure devised by his royal secretary Jeiel and his officer Maaseiah, who reported to Hananiah, one of the king’s commanders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The number of senior leaders of the ancestral houses of his elite forces numbered 2,600.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah commanded an army of 307,500 who could fight formidably on behalf of the king against any enemy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition, Uzziah equipped the entire army with shields, spears, helmets, body armor, bows, and stones for use in slings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also had various siege engines built by skilled designers and placed them on the towers and on the corner ramparts that could fire arrows and very large stones. His reputation spread far and wide, and he was marvelously assisted until he grew very strong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after he had become strong, in his arrogance he acted corruptly and became unfaithful to the Lord his God, and he dared to enter the Lord’s Temple to burn incense on the incense altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Azariah the priest ran after him, along with 80 of the Lord’s valiant priests,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they opposed King Uzziah. “Uzziah, it’s not for you to burn incense to the Lord,” they told him, “but for the priests to do, Aaron’s descendants who are consecrated to burn incense. Leave the sanctuary now, because you have been unfaithful and won’t receive any honor from the Lord God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah flew into a rage while he held in his hand a censer to burn incense. As he got angry at the priests, leprosy broke out all over his forehead right in front of the priests beside the incense altar in the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Azariah the chief priest and all the priests stared at Uzziah, who was infected with leprosy in his forehead! They all rushed at him and hurried him out of the Temple. Uzziah was in a hurry to get out anyway, because the Lord had struck him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Uzziah remained a leper until the day he died. Because he was a leper, he lived in a separate residence and remained disqualified to enter the Lord’s Temple. His son Jotham served in the royal palace, judging the people of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the rest of Uzziah’s accomplishments, from first to last, have been recorded by Amoz’s son Isaiah the prophet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah died, as had his ancestors, and they buried him alongside his ancestors in a grave in a field that belonged to the kings, because they said, “He was a leper.” Uzziah’s son Jotham became king to replace him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jotham was 25 years old when he began his reign, and he reigned for sixteen years in Jerusalem. His mother was Zadok’s daughter Jerusha.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He practiced what the Lord considered to be right, just as his father Uzziah had done, even though he did not enter the Temple. Nevertheless, the people continued acting corruptly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jotham constructed the Upper Gate of the Lord’s Temple and did extensive work on the wall of Ophel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also built cities in the hill country of Judah, along with fortresses and guard towers in the forests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He launched a military excursion against the king of the Ammonites and defeated him. As a result, that year the Ammonites paid 100 talents of silver in tribute, as well as 10,000 kors of wheat and 10,000 kors of barley. The Ammonites continued to pay this same amount in tribute over the following two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jotham grew in power because he had determined to live his life in the presence of the Lord his God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the accomplishments of Jotham’s reign, including all of his military exploits and campaigns, are recorded in the book of the Kings of Israel and Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He started his reign at the age of 25 years and he reigned for sixteen years in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jotham died, as had his fathers, and he was buried in the City of David. His son Ahaz became king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaz was 20 years old when he began to reign, and he reigned 16 years in Jerusalem, but he did not practice what the Lord considered to be right, as his ancestor David had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, he lived like the kings of Israel did. He cast metal images of Baal,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: burned incense in the Ben-hinnom Valley, and burned his sons as an offering, following the detestable activities of the nations whom the Lord had expelled in front of the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sacrificed and burned incense on high places, on the top of hills, and under every green tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As a result, the Lord his God handed Ahaz over to the king of Aram, who defeated him and took a large number of captives away to Damascus. Ahaz was also delivered over to the control of the King of Israel, who defeated him with many heavy casualties.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Remaliah’s son Pekah killed 120,000 soldiers in a single day, all of them elite forces, because they had forsaken the Lord God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zichri, a valiant soldier from Ephraim, killed the king’s son Maaseiah, Azrikam, the palace manager, and Elkanah, who was second in rank to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelis carried away 200,000 women, sons, and daughters from among their own relatives. They also took a great deal of plunder, and brought it all to Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But a prophet of the Lord was there named Oded. He went out to greet the army as it arrived in Samaria. He warned them, “Look! Because the Lord God of your ancestors was angry at Judah, he delivered them into your control, but you have killed them with a vehemence that has reached all the way to heaven!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now you’re intending to make the men and women of Judah and Jerusalem to be your slaves. Surely you have your own sins against the Lord your God for which you’re accountable, don’t you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So listen to me! Return the captives whom you’ve captured from your brothers, because the anger of the Lord is burning hot against you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the leaders of the descendants of Ephraim, including Johanan’s son Azariah, Meshillemoth’s son Berechiah, Shallum’s son Jehizkiah, and Hadlai’s son Amasa, stood up to the army as they were coming back from the battle
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and told them, “Don’t bring those captives here! You’ll bring even more guilt on us from the Lord, in addition to our own existing sin and guilt! He’s already mad enough against Israel because of our guilt!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the army abandoned the captives and the war booty in front of the officers and the entire assembled retinue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, some men who were chosen by name took charge of the captives, clothed those who were naked with clothes appropriated from the war booty, gave them clothes and sandals, fed them, gave them something to drink, anointed them with oil, provided those who weren’t able to walk with donkeys to ride on, and took them back to their relatives at Jericho, the city of palm trees. Then they returned to Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Right about then, King Ahaz sent for help from the kings of Assyria
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because the Edomites had invaded, attacked Judah, and carried off some captives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines also invaded some of the cities in the Shephelah and in the Negev of Judah. They captured Beth-shemesh, Aijalon, Gederoth, Soco, and their surrounding villages, Timnah and its villages, and Gimzo and its villages. Then the Philistines settled there,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because the Lord was humiliating Judah because of King Ahaz of Israel, since Ahaz had brought about a lack of restraint within Judah and had remained unfaithful to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Tiglath-pileser of Assyria attacked Ahaz and, instead of helping him, attacked him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even though Ahaz took some of the assets belonging to the Lord’s Temple from the royal palace, and from the palaces belonging to the princes, and gave them to the king of Assyria, none of his gifts did any good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the midst of his troubles, King Ahaz became more and more unfaithful to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sacrificed to the gods of Damascus that had defeated him, reasoning, “The gods of the kings of Aram helped them, so I’ll sacrifice to them so they will help me!” But those gods brought about his downfall, and the downfall of all of Israel, too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaz also collected the utensils of God’s Temple, cut them all into pieces, and closed the doors of the Lord’s Temple. Then he made altars to himself on every corner in Jerusalem
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and established high places in every city of Judah where incense was burned to other gods, thus provoking the Lord God of his ancestors to anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of his accomplishments, and records of everything he did from first to last are written in the Book of the Kings of Judah and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ahaz died, as had his ancestors, and he was buried in the city of Jerusalem, but they didn’t bury him among the tombs of the kings of Israel. Ahaz’s son Hezekiah reigned in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah began his reign at the age of 25. He reigned for 29 years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Abijah, Zechariah’s daughter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He practiced what the Lord considered to be right, following all of the examples set by his ancestor David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the first month of the first year of his reign he repaired and reopened the doors of the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he brought in the priests and descendants of Levi, gathered them into the square in the eastern part of the Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and told them,
“Pay attention to me, you descendants of Levi! Consecrate yourselves and the Temple of the Lord God of your ancestors by taking out from the Holy Place whatever is unclean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Our ancestors have been unfaithful. They practiced what the Lord considers to be evil, abandoned him, turned their faces away from the place where the Lord resides, and turned their backs to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They shut the doors to the vestibule of the Temple, extinguished its lamps, and have not burned incense or offered burnt offerings to the God of Israel in the Holy Place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That’s why the Lord was angry with Judah and Jerusalem and made them an object of terror, horror, and derision, as you’ve seen with your own eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now look! Our ancestors have been killed with swords and our sons, daughters, and wives are being held captive because of all of this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’m intending to make a covenant with the Lord God of Israel so his burning anger may turn away from us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please don’t be careless, you descendants of Aaron, because the Lord has chosen you to minister in his presence, to serve him, to be his ministers, and to burn incense.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here are the names of the descendants of Levi who made themselves available to God: Amasai’s son Mahath and Azariah’s son Joel from the descendants of Kohath; Abdi’s son Kish and Jehallelel’s son Azariah from the descendants of Merari; Zimmah’s son Joah and Joah’s son Eden from the descendants of Gershon;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elizaphan’s sons Shimri and Jeiel; Asaph’s sons Zechariah and Mattaniah;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Heman’s sons Jehiel and Shimei; and Jeduthun’s sons Shemaiah and Uzziel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also brought together their brothers, consecrated themselves, and proceeded to cleanse the Lord’s Temple, just as the king had ordered in accordance with what the Lord had told him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests entered the inner courts of the Lord’s Temple to cleanse it, and they brought out everything unclean that they found there to the outer court of the Lord’s Temple. Then the descendants of Levi carried everything from there out to the Kidron Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They began their consecration duties on the first day of the first month and finished at the Lord’s outer vestibule on the eighth day of the month. Another eight days was used to consecrate the Lord’s Temple, so they completed the work on the sixteenth day of the first month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, they went to King Hezekiah and told him, “We have cleansed all of the Lord’s Temple, including the altar for burnt offerings, all of its utensils, the table of showbread, and all of its utensils.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition, we have prepared and rededicated all of the utensils that King Ahaz threw away during his unfaithful reign, and now they’re back in service at the Lord’s altar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early the next morning, King Hezekiah got up and assembled the city officials and went up to the Lord’s Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: where they brought seven rams, seven lambs, and seven male goats for a sin offering on behalf of the kingdom, the Holy Place, and Judah. He ordered that the priests, as descendants of Aaron, place the offerings on the Lord’s altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they slaughtered the bulls and the priests sprinkled the blood on the altar. They also slaughtered the rams and sprinkled the blood on the altar, and they also slaughtered the lambs and sprinkled the blood on the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought the male goats for the sin offering to the king within the assembled gathering, laid their hands on them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and then the priests slaughtered them and purged the altar with their blood as a sin offering to atone for all Israel, because the king ordered that the burnt offering and the sin offering be made for all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah stationed descendants of Levi in the Lord’s Temple to play cymbals and stringed instruments, just as David, Gad the seer, and Nathan the prophet had directed, because the command to do so was from the Lord through those prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Levi played instruments that had been crafted by David and the priests sounded trumpets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah gave a command to offer burnt offerings on the altar, and when the burnt offerings began, a song to the Lord also began with trumpets sounding and with the instruments that King David of Israel had crafted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everybody in the assembly worshipped, the singers sang, and the trumpets sounded. They continued doing this until the burnt offering sacrifice was completed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the sacrifices had been offered, the king and everyone else who was present with him bowed down and worshipped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Hezekiah and his officials ordered the descendants of Levi to sing praises to the Lord based on psalms that had been written by David and Asaph the seer. So they all joyfully sang praises, bowed low, and worshipped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Hezekiah announced, “Now that you’ve consecrated yourselves to the Lord, come near and bring your sacrifices and thanksgiving offerings to the Lord’s Temple.” So the assembly brought sacrifices and thanksgiving offerings, and everyone who was willing to do so brought burnt offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The number of burnt offerings brought by the assembly was 70 bulls, 100 rams, and 200 lambs. All of these were burnt offerings to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The consecrated offerings numbered 600 bulls and 3,000 sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because there weren’t enough priests, they were unable to prepare all the burnt offerings until other priests came forward after having consecrated themselves, so their descendant of Levi relatives assisted them until the services were complete. (The descendants of Levi had been more conscientious in consecrating themselves than had been the priests.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, there were also many burnt offerings, fat from peace offerings, and drink offerings. And that’s how the service of the Lord’s Temple was restored.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah and all of the people were ecstatic with joy because of what God had done for the people, since everything had come about so suddenly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah also sent word to all of Israel and Judah, and wrote letters to Ephraim and Manasseh that they should come to the Lord’s Temple in Jerusalem to observe the Passover to the Lord God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king, his princes, and the entire assembly in Jerusalem had mutually decided to observe the Passover in the second month,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but they had been unable to celebrate it then because not enough priests had consecrated themselves and the people had not yet been gathered together in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This decision seemed to be a good one in the opinion of the king and of the entire assembly,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so they published a decree that was circulated throughout Israel from Beer-sheba to Dan that they are to come celebrate the Passover to the Lord God of Israel in Jerusalem. The Passover had not been celebrated in great numbers as was being prescribed by the decree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Couriers were sent throughout all of Israel and Judah with letters written by the king and his princes, just as the king had commanded:
“Listen, you descendants of Israel! Come back to the Lord God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, so he may come back to those of you who have escaped and survived from domination by the kings of Assyria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t be like your ancestors and your relatives, who weren’t faithful to the Lord God of their ancestors, who, as a result, made them a desolate horror, as you well know.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So don’t be stiff-necked like your ancestors were. Instead, submit to the Lord, enter his sanctuary that he has sanctified forever, and serve the Lord your God so that he’ll stop being angry with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you return to the Lord, your relatives and children will receive compassion from those who took them away captive, and they’ll return to this land, because the Lord is both gracious and compassionate—he will not turn away from you if you return to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Couriers crossed from city to city throughout the territories of Ephraim and Manasseh as far as Zebulun, but those people just mocked them and laughed at them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, a few men from Asher, Manasseh, and Zebulun humbled themselves and traveled to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God also poured out his grace throughout Judah, giving them a dedicated heart to do what the king and princes had decreed according to the message from the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many of the people gathered together in Jerusalem to observe the Festival of Unleavened Bread during the second month. It was a very large assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They all got to work and removed the idolatrous altars that were throughout Jerusalem. They also removed all the incense altars and threw them into the Kidron Brook.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then they slaughtered the Passover lamb on the fourteenth day of the second month.
The priests and descendants of Levi felt ashamed of themselves, so they consecrated themselves and brought burnt offerings to the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they took their customary places, as the Law of Moses the man of God prescribes, and the priests sprinkled the blood that they were given by the descendants of Levi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because there were so many in the assembly that had not consecrated themselves, therefore the descendants of Levi supervised the slaughter of the Passover sacrifices on behalf of everyone who remained unclean, so they could be consecrated to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even though a large crowd of people from as far away as Ephraim, Manasseh, Issachar, and Zebulun had not completed consecrating themselves, they still ate the Passover in a manner not proscribed by the Law, because Hezekiah had prayed like this for them: “May the good Lord extend a pardon on behalf of
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: everyone who prepares his own heart to seek God, the Lord God of his ancestors, even though he does so inconsistent with the laws of consecration.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord listened to Hezekiah and healed the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelis who were present in Jerusalem observed the Festival of Unleavened Bread for seven days with immense gladness, and the descendants of Levi and priests praised the Lord throughout each day, singing mightily to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah encouraged all the descendants of Levi who demonstrated significant insight in their service to the Lord, so they all participated in the festival meals for seven days, all the while sacrificing peace offerings and giving thanks to the Lord God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, the whole assembly agreed to celebrate for another seven days, and so they did—and they were very happy to do so!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Hezekiah of Judah gave the assembly 1,000 bulls and 7,000 sheep for offerings, and the princes contributed 1,000 bulls and 10,000 sheep, and a large number of priests consecrated themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone in the assembly of Judah rejoiced, as did the priests, the descendants of Levi, and the people who gathered together from throughout Israel, including those who came from the land of Israel and those who lived in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was great joy throughout Jerusalem, because nothing had happened like this in Jerusalem since the days of David’s son Solomon, king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, the priests arose, blessed the people, and their voices were heard in prayer all the way to heaven, where God resides in holiness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the conclusion of all of these activities, everybody in Israel who was in attendance traveled throughout the cities of Judah, broke down the sacred pillars, cut down the Asherim, and broke down the high places and altars throughout the territories of Judah, Benjamin, Ephraim, and Manasseh until they had eliminated all of them. Then the people of Israel went back to their cities and back to their work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah appointed the priestly divisions and the divisions of the descendants of Levi, each according to their service duties, including both priests and descendants of Levi who offered morning and evening burnt offerings, peace offerings, general ministry, thanksgiving, and praise in the gateways to the Lord’s campgrounds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also gave a portion of his own income for both morning and evening burnt offerings, for burnt offerings on the Sabbath, New Moons, and for the scheduled festivals, as is recorded in the Lord’s Law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah also directed the people who lived in Jerusalem to give what was due to the priests and descendants of Levi, so they could be strengthened in the Lord’s Law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the word spread around, the people of Israel gave generously for the first fruits of grain, wine, oil, honey, and all of the produce of the fields. They generously gave a tithe of everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The descendants of Israel and Judah who lived throughout the cities of Judah also brought tithes of cattle and sheep, as well as tithes of gifts that had been dedicated to the Lord their God.
As these gifts were given, they were laid in piles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They began to make these piles of gifts during the third month, and it took them until the seventh month to finish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hezekiah and the officials arrived and saw the piles of gifts, they blessed the Lord and his people Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Hezekiah quizzed the priests and the descendants of Levi about the piles of gifts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Azariah replied, “Since they began to bring their gifts into the Lord’s Temple, we have eaten and have been satisfied. Now we still have plenty left, because the Lord has blessed his people so that we have all of this left over.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah gave an order to prepare storerooms in the Lord’s Temple, and so they did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They faithfully brought in the gifts, tithes, and consecrated materials, and Conaniah the descendant of Levi was placed in charge of them. His brother Shimei was second in command,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehiel, Azaziah, Nahath, Asahel, Jerimoth, Jozabad, Eliel, Ismachiah, Mahath, and Benaiah served as supervisors under Conaniah and his brother Shimei, who had been appointed by King Hezekiah. Azariah served as senior officer of God’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Imnah the descendant of Levi’s son Kore, keeper of the eastern gate, was in charge of voluntary offerings to God, apportioning contributions for the Lord and the most holy things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Under his authority, Eden, Miniamin, Jeshua, Shemaiah, Amariah, and Shecaniah served in the priestly cities, making sure contributions were distributed faithfully to their relatives division by division, no matter how large or how small,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: without regard to genealogical enrollment, to every male 30 years old and older—that is, to everyone who entered the Lord’s Temple as their duty obligations required—for their work and duties according to their divisions
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: as well as the priests who were enrolled in the genealogies according to their ancestral households.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These genealogical enrollments also included all of their little children, their wives, and their sons and daughters for the entire assembly, because they were being faithful to consecrating themselves in holiness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, with respect to the descendants of Aaron, that is, the priests who lived out in the country away from the cities, or who lived in each and every city, men were designated by name to distribute portions to every male among the priests and to everyone who had been enrolled by genealogy among the descendants of Levi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah did this throughout all of Judah, and he acted well, doing what the Lord his God considered to be right and true.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything that Hezekiah began in the service of God’s Temple was done according to the Law and to the commandments as he sought his God, worked with all of his heart, and became successful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all of these acts of faithfulness occurred, King Sennacherib of Assyria came, invaded Judah, and laid siege to the fortified cities, thinking to conquer them for himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as Hezekiah learned that Sennacherib had arrived and had determined to attack Jerusalem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he developed a plan with his commanders and his elite forces to cut off the water supply from the springs that were outside the city, and they helped him to carry it out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many people gathered together and plugged up all the springs, along with the stream that flowed through the region. They were thinking to themselves, “Why should the Assyrian kings invade and discover an abundant water supply?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah took courage and rebuilt all of the walls that had been broken down. Then he erected watch towers on them, and added another external wall. He fortified the terrace ramparts in the City of David and prepared a large number of weapons and shields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He appointed military officers to take charge of the people, who gathered them together in the square near the city gate and spoke to them encouragingly,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Be strong and courageous. Don’t be afraid or disheartened because of the king of Assyria or because of the army that accompanies him, because the one who is with us is greater than the one with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He only has the strength of his own flesh, but the Lord our God is with us to help us and to fight our battles.” So the people were encouraged from what King Hezekiah of Judah told them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, King Sennacherib of Assyria sent his messengers to Jerusalem while he was in the middle of a vigorous attack on Lachish. They delivered this message to King Hezekiah of Judah and to all the people of Judah who had gathered in Jerusalem:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what King Sennacherib of Assyria says: ‘What are you leaning on that makes you stay behind while Jerusalem comes under siege?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t Hezekiah lying to you so he can hand you over to die by famine and thirst? After all, he’s telling you “The Lord our God will deliver us from the king of Assyria’s control.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t this the very same Hezekiah who removed this god’s high places and altars? Isn’t this the same Hezekiah who issued this order to Judah and Jerusalem: “You are to worship in front of only one altar and burn your sacrifices only on it.”?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t you know what my predecessors have done to all the other people in other lands? Were the gods of the people who lived in those lands able to deliver their countries out of my control?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What god, out of all the gods of those nations that my predecessors utterly destroyed, has been able to deliver his people from my control or from the control of my predecessors?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now therefore, don’t let Hezekiah lie to you or mislead you like this. Don’t believe him, because no god of any nation has been able to deliver his people from my control or from the control of my predecessors. So how much less will your God deliver you from me?’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Sennacherib’s spokesmen said even worse things against the Lord God and against his servant Hezekiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sennacherib also wrote letters like this that insulted and slandered the Lord God of Israel: “Just as the gods of the nations in other lands haven’t delivered their people from my control, so also the god of Hezekiah won’t deliver his people from me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His spokesmen shouted these things out with loud voices in the language of Judah to frighten and terrify the people of Jerusalem who were stationed on the city walls, to make it easier to conquer the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In doing so, they spoke about the God of Jerusalem as if he were like the gods of the nations of the earth that are made by the hands of human beings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, King Hezekiah and Amoz’s son Isaiah the prophet were praying about this and crying out to heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord sent an angel, who eliminated all of the elite forces, commanders, and officers within the encampment of the king of Assyria. As a result, he retreated to his own country, deeply ashamed and humiliated. When he visited the temple of his god, some of his sons killed him right there with swords.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That’s how the Lord delivered Hezekiah, as well as those who lived in Jerusalem, from Assyria’s King Sennacherib and all his forces, and provided for all of their needs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many brought gifts to the Lord in Jerusalem and brought presents to King Hezekiah of Judah. As a result, he was exalted in the opinion of all nations thereafter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During this time Hezekiah became critically ill, and he prayed to the Lord. The Lord spoke to him and gave him a sign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Hezekiah’s response wasn’t commensurate with what had been done for him because he was arrogant in heart, so wrath came upon him, upon Judah, and upon Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Hezekiah humbled himself while he was arrogant in heart, and the inhabitants of Jerusalem joined him in this. As a result, the Lord’s wrath did not come upon them during Hezekiah’s lifetime.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah received immense wealth and honor. He built treasuries for himself to store silver, gold, precious stones, spices, shields, and all sorts of valuable items,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: along with storage facilities for grain, wine, oil, stalls for all sorts of cattle, and sheepfolds for his flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also built cities for himself and stored up flocks and herds in abundance, because God had given him great riches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah stopped up the upper outlet of the Gihon springs and diverted them down to the western side of the City of David. He prospered in everything he did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later on, envoys came from the princes of Babylon to inquire about the miracle that had happened in the land. God left Hezekiah to himself, so that he might make known what was really in Hezekiah’s heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the rest of Hezekiah’s accomplishments and his faithful deeds are recorded in the vision of Amoz’s son Isaiah the prophet, and in the Book of the Kings of Judah and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah died, as had his fathers, and they buried him in the upper part of the tombs of the descendants of David. All of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem honored him at his death. But his son Manasseh reigned in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Manasseh began to reign at the age of twelve years, and continued to reign for 55 years in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he practiced what the Lord considered to be evil by behaving detestably, as did the nations whom the Lord expelled in front of the Israelis.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He re-established the high places that his father Hezekiah had demolished, he built altars to the Baals, erected Asherim, and worshipped and served the armies of heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also built altars in the Lord’s Temple, about which the Lord had spoken “My name will reside in Jerusalem forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built altars for all the armies of heaven in the two courtyards of the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He burned his sons as an offering in the Ben-hinnom Valley, practiced fortune-telling, witchcraft, sorcery, and communicated with mediums and spiritualists. He did a lot of things that the Lord considered to be evil, thus provoking him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also placed an image that he had carved in God’s Temple, the place about which God had told to David and to his son Solomon, “I will place my name in this Temple and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and “I won’t let Israel’s foothold slip on the land that I’ve given to your ancestors, if only they will be careful to keep everything that I commanded them in the Law, in the statutes, and in the ordinance through Moses.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is how Manasseh deceived Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem to practice more evil than the nations whom the Lord had eliminated in front of the Israelis.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord kept on speaking to Manasseh and to his people, but they paid no attention to him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so the Lord brought in the army commanders who worked for the king of Assyria, who captured Manasseh with hooks, bound him in bronze chains, and took him off to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when he was in trouble, he sought the face of the Lord his God, humbled himself magnificently before the God of his ancestors,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and prayed to him. Moved by Manasseh’s entreaties, the Lord heard his supplications and brought him back to his kingdom in Jerusalem. That’s how Manasseh learned that the Lord is God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later on, Manasseh reinforced the outer wall to the City of David on the west side overlooking the Gihon Valley as far as the Fish Gate. He encircled the Ophel, raising it to a great height.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also eliminated the foreign gods and idols from the Lord’s Temple, along with all of the altars that he had built in Jerusalem and on the mountain where the Lord’s Temple was located, and he discarded them outside the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He set up an altar to the Lord, sacrificed peace offerings on it, and ordered Judah to serve the Lord God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even so, the people continued to sacrifice in the high places, but only to the Lord their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now as to the rest of Manasseh’s accomplishments, including his prayer to God and what the seers had to say to him in the name of the Lord God of Israel, they are included among the Acts of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His prayer, how God was moved by him, all of his sin and unfaithfulness, and a record of the sites where he constructed high places, erected Asherim and carved images before he humbled himself are written in the Acts of the Seers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Manasseh died, as had his ancestors, and they buried him in his own palace while his son Amon became king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amon was 22 years old when he became king, and he reigned two years in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He practiced what the Lord considered to be evil, just as his father Manasseh had done, sacrificing to and serving all the carved images that his father Manasseh had made,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: except that he never humbled himself to the Lord like his father Manasseh had done. In fact, Amon multiplied his own guilt
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: until his servants finally conspired against him and executed him in his own palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people of the land executed all of the conspirators against King Amon and installed his son Josiah as king to succeed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Josiah was eight years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for 31 years in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He practiced what the Lord considered to be right, following the example of his ancestor David, turning neither to the right nor to the left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eighth year of his reign, while he was still young, he began to seek the God of his ancestor David. In the twelfth year of his reign, he began to remove the high places, Asherim, carved images, and cast images from Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They tore down the altars of Baals in his presence. He chopped down the incense altars that stood high above them. He broke into pieces the Asherim, the carved images, and the cast images, ground them to dust, and scattered the residue on the graves of those who had sacrificed to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He burned the bones of the priests on their altars, thus purging Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the cities of Manasseh, Ephraim, Simeon, and as far as Naphtali and their surrounding ruins,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he also tore down altars, destroyed the Asherim and the carved images, grinding them into dust, and chopped down all the incense altars throughout the land of Israel. Then he went back to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eighteenth year of his reign, after he had purged the land and the Temple, he sent Azaliah’s son Shaphan, Maaseiah, mayor of Jerusalem, and Joahaz’s son Joah, the recorder, to repair the Temple of the Lord his God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They approached Hilkiah the high priest and delivered to him the money that had been brought into God’s Temple that the descendants of Levi and gatekeepers had collected from Manasseh, Ephraim, the surviving Israelis, Judah, Benjamin, and the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They paid it to the workmen who supervised the Lord’s Temple, and the workmen who were employed in the Lord’s Temple to supervise restoration and repair of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They, in turn, paid the carpenters and builders to purchase quarried stone and timber for binders and beams for the buildings that previous kings of Judah had let deteriorate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The workmen did their duties faithfully with these foremen supervising them: Jahath and Obadiah, descendants of Levi who were Merari’s sons, Zechariah and Meshullam, descendants of Kohath, and various descendants of Levi, who were skilled musicians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These men also supervised the heavy lift workers and supervised all the workmen from job to job, while some of the descendants of Levi served as scribes, officials, and gatekeepers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were bringing out the money that had come in as gifts to the Lord’s Temple, Hilkiah the priest discovered the Book of the Law of the Lord that had been handed down by Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hilkiah reported his finding to Shaphan the scribe, telling him, “I found the Book of the Law in the Lord’s Temple. Then he gave the book to Shaphan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shaphan took the book to the king and gave an additional report to the king, telling him “Everything that you’ve entrusted to your servants is being carried out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They’ve removed the money that was found in the Lord’s Temple and have passed it on to the supervisors and the workmen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shaphan the scribe also informed the king, “Hilkiah the priest gave me a book.” Shaphan read from its contents to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as he heard what the Law said, he tore his clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He issued these orders to Hilkiah, Shaphan’s son Ahikam, Micah’s son Abdon, Shaphan the scribe, and the king’s personal assistant Asaiah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go ask the Lord for me and for those who survive in Israel and in Judah about the words that we’ve read in this book that we found, because the wrath of the Lord that we deserve to have poured out on us is very great, since our ancestors haven’t obeyed the command from the Lord that required us to do everything that is written in this book.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hilkiah and the others who had received orders from the king went to visit Huldah the prophetess, the wife of Tokhath’s son Shallum, grandson of Hasrah. She was the king’s wardrobe supervisor, and she lived in Jerusalem’s Second Quarter. They asked her about what had happened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In response, she replied:
“This is what the Lord God of Israel says: ‘Tell the man who sent you to me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord says: ‘Pay attention! I’m bringing evil to visit this place and its inhabitants—every single curse written in the book that they’ve been reading to the King of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because they abandoned me and have burned incense to other gods, provoking me to become angry at everything they’re doing, therefore my wrath is about to be poured out on this place, and it won’t be quenched.’”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now tell the king of Judah who sent you to ask the Lord about this: ‘This is what the Lord God of Israel says about what you’ve heard:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Because your heart was sensitive, and you humbled yourself before God when you heard what he had to say about this place and its inhabitants—indeed, because you humbled yourself before me, tore your clothes, and cried out to me, I have heard you,” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Look! I’m going to take you to your ancestors, and you will be buried in your grave in peace so that you won’t have to see all the evil that I’m going to bring to this place and to its inhabitants.”’”
So they all brought back this message to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king sent word to gather all the elders of Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king went up to the Lord’s Temple, accompanied by the men of Judah, the inhabitants of Jerusalem, the priests and descendants of Levi, and everyone else from the most important to the least important, and he read out loud all the words of the book of the covenant that had been found in the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While standing in his appointed place, the king made a public covenant with the Lord to follow the Lord, to keep his commandments, his testimonies, and his statutes, and to do so with all of his heart and soul, and to carry out what was written in the covenant contained in the book.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made everyone who was present in Jerusalem and Benjamin to stand in agreement with him. As a result, the inhabitants of Jerusalem reconfirmed the covenant of God, the God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Josiah also removed all the detestable things from the territories that belonged to the people of Israel, and made everyone who lived in Israel to serve the Lord their God. For the rest of his life, they didn’t abandon their quest to follow the Lord God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Josiah observed the Passover to the Lord in Jerusalem. They slaughtered the Passover on the fourteenth day of the first month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He appointed priests to their offices, encouraging them in their service at the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He addressed the descendants of Levi who were teaching all Israel and who had consecrated themselves to the Lord, telling them:
